questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of vaginal bleeding for 2–5 days every 2–3 weeks. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots requiring a thick pad every 2–3 hours. Menarche occurred at 10 years of age, and menses previously occurred at regular 28- to 32-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. Her only medication is a multivitamin. She has no children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 60 years of age. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized uterus. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is the surgical removal of the lining of the uterus and is used to treat benign causes of AUB (e.g., fibroids). Fibroids typically manifest with heavy, regular bleeding rather than the irregular bleeding seen here. While endometrial ablation would reduce this patient's bleeding, it would not be appropriate for the diagnosis or treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, which is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Endometrial sampling is indicated in the diagnostic workup of patients < 45 years of age with any of the following: persistent bleeding despite pharmacological treatment, unopposed estrogen (e.g., due to obesity or polycystic ovary syndrome), or other risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia or neoplasia (e.g., type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Endometrial sampling is also indicated in patients ≥ 45 years of age with any uterine bleeding and postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness > 4 mm. This patient is < 45 years of age and has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is an endometrial biopsy.

A pelvic ultrasound should be considered in patients with AUB to rule out structural abnormalities (e.g., leiomyomas) and evaluate endometrial thickness. However, because endometrial thickness significantly varies during the menstrual cycle in reproductive-age individuals, pelvic ultrasound is not required before performing an endometrial biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound may be used in the workup of AUB. However, transvaginal rather than abdominal ultrasound is indicated to rule out structural anomalies and evaluate endometrial thickness. Moreover, a more sensitive diagnostic test is often used first-line in premenopausal patients < 45 years of age with persistent bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) are commonly used to treat AUB in premenopausal patients, as COCPs typically reduce dysmenorrhea and make bleeding lighter and more regular. While this patient has AUB, she also has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), which warrants further investigation, and, therefore, another step should be performed before the initiation of medical management.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclic progestin therapy can be used to control heavy menstrual bleeding in premenopausal patients with AUB. However, this patient has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche) that warrant further investigation. Therefore, an additional diagnostic step should be completed before initiating management.
questions.hint: Obesity is associated with unopposed estrogen stimulation. This unopposed stimulation is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia, which can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). Patients with AUB with a normal initial laboratory workup and a negative pregnancy test should be evaluated based on their bleeding pattern and risk factors for endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of heavy vaginal bleeding, requiring more than 5 pads per day. Menarche was at the age of 10 years. Menopause occurred 1 year ago. She has a history of hypothyroidism and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 5 years ago. Current medications include levothyroxine and metformin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild vaginal atrophy and a normal cervix. The uterus and adnexa are nontender to palpation. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. Endometrial biopsy shows noninvasive proliferation of endometrial glands with no nuclear or cytological atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy is the only curative treatment for endometrial hyperplasia and is the treatment of choice for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in premenopausal women with completed childbearing or no future desire to conceive and postmenopausal women. As the biopsy shows endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, less invasive treatment options are indicated. If atypia is present in future biopsies, surgery should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Estrogen vaginal cream is used to treat symptomatic vaginal atrophy in postmenopausal women. Although this patient shows signs of vaginal atrophy on physical exam, she did not report any symptoms (e.g., vaginal soreness or dryness) that would warrant therapy for it. Moreover, increasing estrogen exposure could worsen the endometrial hyperplasia, which occurs due to prolonged estrogen exposure unopposed by progestin.

C) INCORRECT:

This postmenopausal patient has endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, which is associated with a low risk of progression to endometrial cancer. Reassurance and follow-up is, therefore, not sufficient and medical treatment should be initiated. Expectant management with close monitoring should only be considered if medical therapy is contraindicated (e.g., progesterone receptor-positive breast cancer), declined, or not tolerated by the patient.

D) CORRECT:

Obese postmenopausal women with early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity, as is the case in this patient, are at an increased risk of developing endometrial hyperplasia. Biopsy confirmed the absence of atypia, so the treatment of choice in this patient is progestin therapy. Progestin opposes the stimulating effect of estrogen on the endometrium, thereby preventing hyperplasia and the occurrence of heavy vaginal bleeding. Good regression rates have been reported in > 98% of women after 3–6 months of progestin therapy. Follow-up with ultrasound after 3–6 months of conservative treatment is recommended to rule out progression to endometrial hyperplasia with atypia or endometrial carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical endometrial ablation, which is the resection of the uterine lining, is used to manage severe menorrhagia in premenopausal women. The procedure is contraindicated in postmenopausal patients with endometrial hyperplasia or endometrial cancer because it disrupts the endometrial structure and precludes further histologic analysis for endometrial hyperplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that is typically used in the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Because it inhibits endogenous estrogen production, anastrozole can reduce the proliferation of the endometrium, which is induced by estrogen. However, while some studies have demonstrated its efficacy for endometrial hyperplasia in postmenopausal women, this medication is not routinely recommended.
questions.hint: In postmenopausal women, endometrial thickness > 4 mm with no evidence of atypia or invasion on endometrial biopsy, is diagnostic of endometrial hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of irregular heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche at the age of 16 years. Menses occur at irregular 15- to 45-day intervals and last 7 to 10 days. She has also noted increased hair growth on her face. She has acne vulgaris treated with topical retinoids. Her 70-year-old grandmother has breast cancer. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows copious cervical mucus and slightly enlarged irregular ovaries. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma is a rare type of gestational trophoblastic disease that only develops after fertilization and implantation of the oocyte. This patient with PCOS actually has a lower risk of developing choriocarcinoma, as chronic anovulation is a hallmark of PCOS, which renders the patient infertile.

B) CORRECT:

In the normal menstrual cycle, estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) is opposed by a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Chronic anovulation in PCOS results in prolonged estrogen exposure of the endometrium unopposed by progesterone, which increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US. This malignancy primarily affects postmenopausal women (peak incidence at 65–74 years) and abnormal uterine bleeding is the main symptom, with later stages manifesting with pelvic pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid lymphoma is a complication of Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the US. Although hypothyroidism would explain this patient's obesity and menstrual irregularities, the absence of additional features, such as fatigue, cold intolerance, dry skin, hair loss, loss of appetite, and constipation, make a thyroid disorder unlikely. Hypothyroidism would also not cause this patient's hirsutism, cystic acne, and enlarged irregular ovaries.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is strongly associated with human papillomavirus infection and the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in developed countries have significantly declined since the introduction of routine Pap smear screening. There is insufficient evidence to confirm that PCOS is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women due to a decline in the protective effect of estrogen on bone after menopause. PCOS may be associated with a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of osteoporosis, but another complication is more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

The catabolic effect of hypercortisolism on protein metabolism in Cushing syndrome can result in muscle atrophy and weakness that is most pronounced in the proximal muscles. Cushing syndrome can also manifest with obesity, hirsutism, acne, and irregular menstrual cycles. However, this patient has no other characteristic features of Cushing syndrome (e.g., thinning skin, hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas, sleep disturbance, depression, and hypertension). PCOS is not associated with an increased risk of proximal myopathy.

G) INCORRECT:

Although PCOS is associated with prolonged estrogen exposure (due to anovulatory cycles and nulliparity), which is a known risk factor for the development of breast cancer, studies were unable to confirm an increased risk of breast cancer in patients with PCOS.
questions.hint: Hyperandrogenic anovulation (as evidenced by delayed menarche, irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne) and obesity are characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of intermittent vaginal spotting. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Menopause occurred at 56 years of age. She has no children. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 83 kg (183 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows traces of blood in the vaginal canal. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 12 mm and normal adnexae. An endometrial biopsy shows hyperplasia with atypia, disorganized glandular tissue, and myometrial invasion. Chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose progestins can be considered in young patients with early-stage endometrial cancer confined to the uterus who desire future pregnancies. Since the preservation of fertility is not a priority for this 67-year-old patient, a different intervention should be considered.

B) CORRECT:

Endometrial cancer is associated with a number of risk factors, including nulliparity, late menopause, and obesity, and should always be considered in a patient with postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. Total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH/BSO) is the best management option for patients with endometrial cancer who do not wish to preserve fertility or have reached menopause. TAH/BSO is typically performed using a minimally invasive approach (e.g., laparoscopy) unless contraindications are present (e.g., peritoneal adhesions). Cancer staging, including the assessment of local lymph node involvement, is performed during surgery. TAH/BSO alone is usually curative in patients whose disease is confined to the uterus with no evidence of metastatic spread. For patients with advanced-stage disease, adjuvant therapy should be considered (e.g., pelvic radiation therapy, chemotherapy).

C) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive therapy (COCP) is a treatment option for some types of abnormal uterine bleeding. However, this patient's bleeding is most likely due to endometrial cancer, for which COCP therapy is not generally recommended. Although COCPs have a protective effect on the endometrium, there is little evidence about their efficacy for the treatment of endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation and curettage (D&C) may be used for endometrial tissue sampling in patients with suspected endometrial hyperplasia or cancer. However, D&C is not commonly performed for this indication because there are less invasive methods of tissue sampling available. Moreover, this patient's diagnosis was already confirmed on endometrial biopsy, so additional endometrial sampling is not necessary.
Image Description:

A gynecological procedure in which the cervix is widened using dilators of increasing diameters (left image) in order to allow insertion of a curette into the uterus for therapeutic or diagnostic tissue removal (right image).

E) INCORRECT:

Pelvic radiation therapy can be used as adjuvant therapy in patients with endometrial cancer with myometrial invasion. However, it is only used after the first-line treatment has been administered. This patient has not received any treatment and therefore requires a different intervention at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's biopsy and imaging results are consistent with endometrial cancer.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man was admitted for a bowel obstruction and found to have a large obstructing colonic adenocarcinoma just proximal to the hepatic flexure. He underwent a successful right hemicolectomy. Pathology was consistent with an obstructing, 9-cm colon adenocarcinoma, with no evidence of lymph node involvement in 17 sampled nodes.
When asked about his family history, the patient states that his mother and maternal aunt were diagnosed with endometrial cancer at ages 56 and 59, respectively. His mother has no other siblings, but her father died in his early 40s of an unknown cause after several months of worsening abdominal pain and weight loss. The patient has two younger siblings and three children, all of whom are healthy.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by the development of gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps; the development of small, dark-colored spots on the lips, around and inside the mouth, near the eyes and nostrils, and around the anus; and an increased risk for cancers of the gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, cervix, ovary, and breast.

B) INCORRECT:

BRCA mutations are associated with premature breast and ovarian cancers and, to a lesser extent, pancreatic and prostate cancers.

C) CORRECT:

There are two principal inherited colorectal cancer syndromes: familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; also known as Lynch syndrome). This patient’s history of a large right-sided colon cancer, in combination with his family history of endometrial cancer, strongly suggests HNPCC.

Compared with FAP, HNPCC usually causes larger, less-aggressive right-sided colon cancers. When systemic treatment is needed, HNPCC colon tumors are thought to be more responsive to chemotherapy than FAP tumors. HNPCC also causes endometrial cancer and, to a lesser extent, cancers of the ovary, stomach, small bowel, pancreas, hepatobiliary tract, brain, and upper uroepithelial tract.

Key learning point: Other than colorectal cancer, the most common cancer associated with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome) is endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is associated with breast cancer, sarcoma, brain tumors, and leukemia.

E) INCORRECT:

FAP tends to cause aggressive distal colonic lesions in a background of colonic polyposis and also predisposes patients to duodenal polyps, gastric cancer, and abdominal desmoid tumors.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of obesity reports 2 months of irregular vaginal bleeding. Ten years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and treated successfully with surgery, radiation therapy, and tamoxifen. She has no family history of breast or gynecologic cancer. Physical examination, including a pelvic examination, is normal. Her most recent Pap test, performed one year ago, was normal, with negative testing for human papillomavirus.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Operative dilatation and curettage of the endometrium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Pap test is most useful for cervical cancer screening and is not used to evaluate endometrial cancer. This patient is up to date on her cervical cancer screening; her next routine screening would not be due for another 4 years. The recent negative result also makes cervical cancer an unlikely cause of her postmenopausal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographic imaging could be considered as an alternative to endometrial biopsy in this case, but the imaging should be done via transvaginal ultrasound rather than CT or MRI of the pelvis. Although an ultrasound would be acceptable, an endometrial biopsy is typically preferred because it is a simple procedure with a high sensitivity and provides tissue diagnosis. If an ultrasound is pursued, then the thickness of the endometrium is used to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. Typically, an endometrial thickness of <4 mm in patients with postmenopausal bleeding reliably excludes endometrial cancer; the negative predictive value approaches 99%. Patients who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Operative dilatation and curettage is unnecessarily invasive and is not indicated for the initial evaluation of a woman with postmenopausal bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Irregular vaginal bleeding in a postmenopausal woman should raise concern for endometrial cancer. Risk factors for endometrial cancer include obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, use of estrogen replacement therapy, use of tamoxifen, older age, and certain familial genetic disorders such as Lynch syndrome. Endometrial cancer is most often diagnosed in the sixth decade of life; complex endometrial hyperplasia can increase the risk.

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen-receptor modulator. Although its primary therapeutic effect in breast cancer treatment is due to its antiestrogenic properties, this drug also has modest estrogenic activity. In standard doses, it can be associated with endometrial proliferation, hyperplasia, polyp formation, and uterine carcinoma and sarcoma. Screening for endometrial cancer with routine transvaginal ultrasonography, endometrial biopsy, or both has not been shown to be effective in asymptomatic patients using tamoxifen.

Postmenopausal women who experience vaginal bleeding and have a history of tamoxifen use should undergo evaluation with in-office endometrial biopsy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a postmenopausal woman who was treated with tamoxifen for several years and now presents with irregular vaginal bleeding is an in-office endometrial biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiographic imaging could be considered as an alternative to endometrial biopsy in this case, but the imaging should be done via transvaginal ultrasound rather than CT or MRI of the pelvis. Although an ultrasound would be acceptable, an endometrial biopsy is typically preferred because it is a simple procedure with a high sensitivity and provides tissue diagnosis. If an ultrasound is pursued, then the thickness of the endometrium is used to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. Typically, an endometrial thickness of <4 mm in patients with postmenopausal bleeding reliably excludes endometrial cancer; the negative predictive value approaches 99%. Patients who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes reports two episodes of vaginal bleeding during the past 6 months. On each occasion, light spotting lasted for approximately 3 days. She experienced natural menopause at age 53.
The remainder of her review of systems is negative. Physical examination is unremarkable. A transvaginal ultrasound shows a 7-mm endometrial stripe.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A progesterone challenge test is used in the evaluation of amenorrhea in premenopausal women, not for the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation with repeat ultrasound in 6 months is not adequate in this situation.

C) INCORRECT:

A hysterectomy is sometimes indicated for persistent, bothersome postmenopausal bleeding, but a presurgical endometrial biopsy to evaluate for malignancy should be the first step, even in those cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound is superior to pelvic CT for uterine imaging. Performing CT in this patient would not add useful information.

E) CORRECT:

Postmenopausal bleeding is always considered abnormal and should prompt evaluation of the endometrium. Possible causes include vaginal or endometrial atrophy, endometrial polyps, cervical malignancy, and endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. Fewer than 10% of women with postmenopausal bleeding have endometrial malignancy.

When the endometrial lining is 4 mm or less, transvaginal ultrasound has a negative predictive value for endometrial cancer that approaches 99%. Women who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation; this may consist of in-office endometrial biopsy, hysteroscopy with biopsy, or dilation and curettage.

A hysterectomy is sometimes indicated for persistent, bothersome postmenopausal bleeding, but presurgical endometrial sampling to evaluate for malignancy should be the first step, even in those cases.

Key learning point: Postmenopausal bleeding requires further workup in a woman with an ultrasound-measured endometrial stripe of greater than 4 mm.

questions.text: A 19-year-old nulligravid woman presents with irregular heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche at the age of 16 years. Menses occur at irregular 15- to 45-day intervals and last 7 to 10 days. She has also noted increased hair growth on her face. She has acne vulgaris treated with topical retinoids. Her 70-year-old grandmother has breast cancer. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows copious cervical mucus and slightly enlarged irregular ovaries. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma is a rare type of gestational trophoblastic disease that only develops after fertilization and implantation of the oocyte. This patient with PCOS actually has a lower risk of developing choriocarcinoma, as chronic anovulation is a hallmark of PCOS, which renders the patient infertile.

B) CORRECT:

In the normal menstrual cycle, estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) is opposed by a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Chronic anovulation in PCOS results in prolonged estrogen exposure of the endometrium unopposed by progesterone, which increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US. This malignancy primarily affects postmenopausal women (peak incidence at 65–74 years) and abnormal uterine bleeding is the main symptom, with later stages manifesting with pelvic pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is strongly associated with human papillomavirus infection and the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in developed countries have significantly declined since the introduction of routine Pap smear screening. There is insufficient evidence to confirm that PCOS is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women due to a decline in the protective effect of estrogen on bone after menopause. PCOS may be associated with a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of osteoporosis, but another complication is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Although PCOS is associated with prolonged estrogen exposure (due to anovulatory cycles and nulliparity), which is a known risk factor for the development of breast cancer, studies were unable to confirm an increased risk of breast cancer in patients with PCOS.
questions.hint: Hyperandrogenic anovulation (as evidenced by delayed menarche, irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne) and obesity are characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic with a three-day history of painless vaginal bleeding. She is 12 years post-menopausal and has type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has been on combined estrogen-progesterone hormone replacement therapy for three years. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals no abnormal masses or lesions. A transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial stripe measuring 7 mm. Laboratory results are unremarkable (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Endometrial stripe measuring 7 mm
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Stop hormone replacement therapy and observe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilation and curettage is more invasive and typically reserved for cases where office biopsy is not feasible or when focal lesions are suspected. This patient’s stable condition and ultrasound findings suggest that an office biopsy is sufficient for initial evaluation, avoiding unnecessary procedural risks.

B) CORRECT:

Office endometrial biopsy is the appropriate next step for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding in this patient. Her risk factors, including obesity, type 2 diabetes, and hormone replacement therapy, increase the likelihood of endometrial pathology such as hyperplasia or carcinoma. An endometrial thickness greater than 4-5 mm on transvaginal ultrasound, as seen with her 7 mm measurement, warrants histopathological evaluation. This minimally invasive procedure can be performed in an outpatient setting, providing timely and efficient tissue sampling for diagnosis.

Key learning point: In post-menopausal women with vaginal bleeding, an endometrial biopsy is essential to diagnose potential endometrial pathology, such as hyperplasia or cancer, especially in the presence of risk factors like obesity, diabetes, and hormone replacement therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeating the ultrasound in 3 months is not appropriate given the patient's postmenopausal bleeding and risk factors for endometrial pathology. An endometrial stripe of 7 mm in this context necessitates immediate histological evaluation to rule out hyperplasia or carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

While hormone replacement therapy can cause endometrial proliferation and irregular bleeding, this patient’s endometrial stripe of 7 mm exceeds the expected thickness for a postmenopausal woman. Her risk factors, including obesity and diabetes, further suggest the need for immediate evaluation rather than observation.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman presents with intermittent vaginal spotting for one month. She has been menopausal for 12 years. Her medical history includes hypertension and obesity. She denies abdominal or pelvic pain, new medications, or supplemental hormone use, and has had no previous gynecologic procedures. Physical examination reveals no vulvar or cervical lesions, and the pelvic exam is unremarkable (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.0 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Total T4
100 nmol/L
64 - 155 nmol/L


Hemoglobin
132 g/L
120 - 160 g/L



Transvaginal ultrasound: Endometrial thickness of 9 mm
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Postmenopausal bleeding in a woman with risk factors such as advanced age and obesity necessitates evaluation for endometrial pathology. An endometrial thickness of 9 mm in a postmenopausal patient exceeds the typical threshold of less than 4 mm, raising concern for endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. Endometrial biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that provides histopathological analysis to detect cellular atypia and malignancy. This procedure is essential for accurate diagnosis and guiding management, distinguishing between benign and neoplastic conditions.

Key learning point: In postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding and increased endometrial thickness, endometrial sampling is the appropriate procedure to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose progestin therapy is used for endometrial hyperplasia in specific cases, such as younger women wishing to preserve fertility. In a postmenopausal woman with a thickened endometrium, initiating therapy without tissue sampling may delay the detection of endometrial carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Serial imaging is not appropriate when notable findings, such as a thickened endometrium, are present in a postmenopausal woman with bleeding. An endometrial thickness of 9 mm significantly exceeds typical thresholds, necessitating histopathological assessment rather than watchful waiting.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic MRI is useful for staging known malignancies but not for initial evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding. The priority is obtaining a histopathologic diagnosis through endometrial biopsy, as MRI does not provide cellular-level information needed to confirm or rule out pathology.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman is evaluated in the Outpatient Gynecology Suite for intermittent light postmenopausal bleeding over the past two months. She denies pelvic pain, fevers, or abnormal discharge. Physical examination is normal. A transvaginal ultrasound shows an endometrial thickness of 7 mm (normal <4 mm). An office endometrial biopsy is planned to investigate possible endometrial pathology. The procedure is scheduled without sedation. The patient expresses concern about the procedure and asks if she must sign a detailed written consent form before proceeding (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Endometrial thickness of 7 mm (normal <4 mm)
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step regarding informed consent for her endometrial biopsy?

choices.text: Explain the procedure thoroughly and proceed with verbal consent
Reassure her that no consent is required for minor office procedures
Obtain a signed general anesthesia form
Postpone the procedure until a detailed written consent can be witnessed

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An office endometrial biopsy is minimally invasive, low-risk, and typically performed without sedation, allowing for verbal informed consent. This involves explaining the procedure's purpose, steps, potential risks (e.g., discomfort, bleeding, infection), benefits, and alternatives. Documenting verbal consent in the clinical record ensures the patient understands and agrees to proceed, aligning with guidelines for minor office procedures.

Key learning point: Verbal consent is typically sufficient for an endometrial biopsy, which is a minimally invasive procedure performed in an outpatient setting without the need for anesthesia or operating room setup.

B) INCORRECT:

Invasive procedures, including endometrial biopsy, require formal consent to inform patients of potential risks and benefits. Even minor procedures necessitate documented consent to uphold ethical and medicolegal standards, ensuring patient autonomy and informed decision-making.

C) INCORRECT:

General anesthesia is not used in an office endometrial biopsy, which is performed without sedation. Consent should focus on the biopsy's specific risks and benefits, not those associated with general anesthesia, which involves different risks such as airway management issues.

D) INCORRECT:

Postponing for a witnessed written consent is unnecessary for a low-risk, office-based endometrial biopsy. The standard consent process involves discussing the procedure's nature, benefits, risks, and alternatives. Delaying could hinder timely evaluation of abnormal endometrial thickening.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents with intermittent heavy vaginal bleeding for two months to the clinic. Her last menstrual period was one year ago. She has no significant medical history except for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy at age 45 and takes no medications. She denies smoking or alcohol use and has never been pregnant. She is 170 cm tall and weighs 65 kg. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged, non-tender uterus with no adnexal abnormalities.
Which factor in her history most strongly increases her risk for the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no established link between abstaining from alcohol and increased risk for endometrial pathology. Factors like prolonged unopposed estrogen exposure, seen in nulliparity or obesity, are primary contributors to endometrial cancer risk. Lack of alcohol use does not affect estrogen metabolism in a way that promotes endometrial proliferation.

B) CORRECT:

Nulliparity is a significant risk factor for endometrial cancer due to prolonged unopposed estrogen exposure. In women who have never been pregnant, the endometrium experiences continuous estrogen-driven proliferation without the counterbalancing effect of progesterone, which occurs during pregnancy. This persistent stimulation increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia, a precursor to carcinoma. Estrogen promotes endometrial cell proliferation, leading to genetic instability and potential malignant transformation when not balanced by progesterone. This risk is particularly relevant in patients without other risk factors, such as obesity.

Key learning point: Nulliparity is a risk factor for endometrial cancer due to increased lifetime exposure to estrogen without the protective effects of progesterone during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of cholecystectomy, typically related to benign gallstone disease, does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer. While hormonal influences may contribute to both gallstone formation and uterine changes, cholecystectomy itself is not linked to the hormonal imbalances or unopposed estrogen exposure that are risk factors for endometrial pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

While the incidence of endometrial cancer increases with age, being over 50 years old is more indicative of typical presentation timing rather than a strong independent risk factor. Age reflects cumulative hormonal exposure but does not directly predispose the endometrium to pathological changes as other factors, such as hormonal imbalances, do.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of progressively heavier and more frequent menstrual bleeding and occasional spotting between periods. She reports no pelvic pain. Her Pap smear results from last year were normal. Pelvic examination reveals a mildly enlarged, nontender uterus. She requests a therapeutic intervention to control her abnormal bleeding.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Levonorgestrel IUD reduces menstrual flow by thinning the endometrium, effective for benign causes of heavy bleeding. However, in women over 45, abnormal bleeding necessitates evaluation for endometrial pathology before hormonal intervention. Using the IUD without diagnosis could delay identifying serious conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopic polypectomy removes endometrial polyps, but the patient's presentation lacks evidence of a polyp. Initial evaluation should include noninvasive methods like transvaginal ultrasound or endometrial sampling to assess for hyperplasia or malignancy. A mildly enlarged, nontender uterus is nonspecific and does not confirm a polyp.

C) INCORRECT:

Combination oral contraceptives regulate menstrual cycles and manage abnormal bleeding in younger women with anovulatory cycles. However, in women over 45, abnormal bleeding requires evaluation for endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. Initiating oral contraceptives could mask symptoms and delay diagnosis, as a normal Pap smear does not exclude endometrial pathology.

D) CORRECT:

In women over 45 with abnormal uterine bleeding, an endometrial biopsy is crucial to evaluate for endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. The risk of premalignant changes or cancer increases with age, making histological examination essential. This minimally invasive procedure provides direct tissue sampling, differentiating between benign and serious conditions, and aligns with the standard of care for perimenopausal women with abnormal bleeding.

Key learning point: In women over 45 with abnormal uterine bleeding, obtaining an endometrial sample is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma before initiating treatment.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman presents to the clinic with four months of irregular, heavy menstrual bleeding. Her cycles were previously regular, and menarche occurred at age 11. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. She has a BMI of 34 kg/m2. She denies pelvic pain or postcoital bleeding. Examination shows no significant pelvic pathology. She is concerned about cancer risk. She does not smoke or drink alcohol (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.2 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Human chorionic gonadotropin
0.3 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL



Transvaginal ultrasound: Endometrial thickness of 10 mm with no focal lesions
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In perimenopausal women with irregular, heavy menstrual bleeding and risk factors such as obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus, endometrial sampling is crucial. These factors increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma due to unopposed estrogen exposure from peripheral aromatization of androgens. The ultrasound finding of increased endometrial thickness further necessitates histopathological evaluation to assess for hyperplasia or malignancy. Endometrial sampling provides definitive tissue analysis, guiding appropriate management and addressing the patient's concern about cancer risk.

Key learning point: In obese women, increased peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens in adipose tissue can lead to unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, resulting in endometrial hyperplasia and irregular bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

The levonorgestrel intrauterine device (IUD) reduces heavy menstrual bleeding by inducing endometrial thinning. However, in a 49-year-old woman with risk factors for endometrial pathology and increased endometrial thickness, it does not provide the necessary histological evaluation to exclude hyperplasia or malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI of the pelvis is useful for staging confirmed malignancies by assessing local invasion. However, in this patient with abnormal uterine bleeding and risk factors, the priority is obtaining a tissue diagnosis through endometrial sampling, as imaging alone cannot confirm hyperplasia or carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pills regulate menstrual cycles and reduce unopposed estrogen effects. However, in a 49-year-old woman with risk factors for endometrial pathology and increased endometrial thickness, they do not replace the need for histological evaluation to assess for hyperplasia or malignancy.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman presents with intermittent postmenopausal spotting for two months. She has a 12-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a body weight in the 95th percentile for her age. She denies using hormone replacement therapy. Pelvic examination is normal (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Insulin
30 mIU/L
2 - 25 mIU/L


Transvaginal ultrasound: Endometrial stripe measuring 11 mm
Which of the following factors most likely contributes to her increased risk of endometrial pathology?

choices.text: Decreased insulin production leading to lower progesterone secretion
Elevated luteinizing hormone causing overstimulation of the endometrium
Direct endometrial cell injury from chronic hyperglycemia
Reduced sex hormone-binding globulin resulting in elevated free estrogen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient has elevated serum insulin, typical of type 2 diabetes mellitus, characterized by insulin resistance and compensatory hyperinsulinemia. This condition, along with obesity, leads to an estrogen-dominant state due to peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens. The risk of endometrial pathology arises from unopposed estrogen exposure, not decreased insulin production or progesterone secretion.

B) INCORRECT:

Postmenopausal women have elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) due to reduced ovarian estrogen production. However, LH primarily stimulates ovarian theca cells, and its role in endometrial hyperplasia is not well established. The risk of endometrial pathology is more directly related to increased unopposed estrogen exposure from adipose tissue aromatization and hyperinsulinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic hyperglycemia contributes to diabetic complications but is not a direct cause of endometrial hyperplasia. Elevated insulin levels reduce sex hormone-binding globulin, increasing free estrogen and acting as a growth factor, leading to unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium. Obesity further promotes endometrial proliferation through increased aromatization of androgens to estrogens.

D) CORRECT:

Obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus are associated with hyperinsulinemia, which reduces hepatic production of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG). This reduction increases free circulating estrogen, leading to unopposed estrogen exposure to the endometrium. Chronic unopposed estrogen stimulation can cause endometrial hyperplasia and potentially malignant transformation. Additionally, adipose tissue increases estrogen levels through enhanced aromatization of androgens, further elevating the risk of endometrial pathology.

Key learning point: Diabetes mellitus is a risk factor for endometrial cancer due to its association with obesity and hyperinsulinemia, which can increase estrogen levels.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic concerned about her risk for a familial inherited cancer condition. Her 55-year-old mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer three years ago and has a specific pathogenic mutation in the BRCA1 gene. She requests genetic evaluation to clarify her own risk. Her paternal history is noncontributory. Physical examination is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in confirming whether she carries the familial mutation?

choices.text: Targeted testing for the known BRCA1 mutation
Full sequencing of BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

When a specific pathogenic variant is identified in a family member, targeted testing for that mutation is the most efficient approach. This method directly assesses whether the individual carries the familial BRCA1 mutation, avoiding unnecessary analysis of other genetic regions. It minimizes the risk of identifying variants of uncertain significance and reduces turnaround time. Targeted testing provides clear results that inform surveillance and management strategies.

Key learning point: When a specific familial genetic mutation is known, targeted testing for that variant is the most appropriate and efficient method for diagnosing family members.

B) INCORRECT:

Whole exome sequencing analyzes nearly all protein-coding regions of the genome. However, it is not appropriate here because the familial BRCA1 mutation is already known. Targeted testing is more focused, cost-effective, and avoids the potential for incidental findings, which are unnecessary when the familial mutation is identified.

C) INCORRECT:

Full sequencing of BRCA1 and BRCA2 is used when there is no known familial mutation. In this case, a specific BRCA1 mutation is already identified in the family, making targeted testing more efficient. Full sequencing may identify additional variants, complicating interpretation and increasing time and cost.

D) INCORRECT:

Karyotype analysis detects large-scale chromosomal abnormalities but cannot identify small-scale mutations like those in BRCA1. The familial mutation involves a point mutation or small insertion/deletion, which requires molecular genetic testing rather than karyotyping.

questions.text: You are seeing a 19-year-old nulligravid woman who presents with irregular, heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche at age 16. Her menses occur at irregular intervals of 15 to 45 days and last 7 to 10 days. She has also noticed increased facial hair growth. She is being treated for acne vulgaris with topical retinoids. Her grandmother, age 70, has breast cancer. She is 163 cm tall and weighs 82 kg; BMI is 31. On pelvic examination, there is copious cervical mucus and the ovaries are slightly enlarged and irregular. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women due to a decline in the protective effect of estrogen on bone after menopause. PCOS may be associated with a decrease in bone density and an increased risk of osteoporosis, but another complication is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Although PCOS is associated with prolonged estrogen exposure (due to anovulatory cycles and nulliparity), which is a known risk factor for the development of breast cancer, studies were unable to confirm an increased risk of breast cancer in patients with PCOS.

C) CORRECT:

In the normal menstrual cycle, estrogen-driven endometrial proliferation (proliferative phase) is opposed by a progesterone-driven secretory phase. Chronic anovulation in PCOS results in prolonged estrogen exposure of the endometrium unopposed by progesterone, which increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US. This malignancy primarily affects postmenopausal women (peak incidence at 65–74 years) and abnormal uterine bleeding is the main symptom, with later stages manifesting with pelvic pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and weight loss.

Key learning point: Chronic anovulation in polycystic ovary syndrome leads to unopposed estrogen exposure, significantly increasing the long-term risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is strongly associated with human papillomavirus infection and the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer in developed countries have significantly declined since the introduction of routine Pap smear screening. There is insufficient evidence to confirm that PCOS is associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma is a rare type of gestational trophoblastic disease that only develops after fertilization and implantation of the oocyte. This patient with PCOS actually has a lower risk of developing choriocarcinoma, as chronic anovulation is a hallmark of PCOS, which renders the patient infertile.
questions.hint: Hyperandrogenic anovulation (as evidenced by delayed menarche, irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne) and obesity are characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of vaginal bleeding for 2–5 days every 2–3 weeks. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots requiring a thick pad every 2–3 hours. Menarche occurred at 10 years of age, and menses previously occurred at regular 28- to 32-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. Her only medication is a multivitamin. She has no children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 60 years of age. The patient is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
36.6°C (97.8°F)


Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg


Heart rate
86/min


Pelvic examination reveals a normal-sized uterus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The most appropriate next step in management is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is the surgical removal of the lining of the uterus and is used to treat benign causes of AUB (e.g., fibroids). Fibroids typically manifest with heavy, regular bleeding rather than the irregular bleeding seen here. While endometrial ablation would reduce this patient's bleeding, it would not be appropriate for the diagnosis or treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, which is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound may be used in the workup of AUB. However, transvaginal rather than abdominal ultrasound is indicated to rule out structural anomalies and evaluate endometrial thickness. Moreover, a more sensitive diagnostic test is often used first-line in premenopausal patients < 45 years of age with persistent bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), as seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Endometrial sampling is indicated in the diagnostic workup of patients < 45 years of age with any of the following: persistent bleeding despite pharmacological treatment, unopposed estrogen (e.g., due to obesity or polycystic ovary syndrome), or other risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia or neoplasia (e.g., type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Endometrial sampling is also indicated in patients ≥ 45 years of age with any uterine bleeding and postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness > 4 mm. This patient is < 45 years of age and has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is an endometrial biopsy.

A pelvic ultrasound should be considered in patients with AUB to rule out structural abnormalities (e.g., leiomyomas) and evaluate endometrial thickness. However, because endometrial thickness significantly varies during the menstrual cycle in reproductive-age individuals, pelvic ultrasound is not required before performing an endometrial biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyclic progestin therapy can be used to control heavy menstrual bleeding in premenopausal patients with AUB. However, this patient has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche) that warrant further investigation. Therefore, an additional diagnostic step should be completed before initiating management.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) are commonly used to treat AUB in premenopausal patients, as COCPs typically reduce dysmenorrhea and make bleeding lighter and more regular. While this patient has AUB, she also has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), which warrants further investigation, and, therefore, another step should be performed before the initiation of medical management.
questions.hint: Obesity is associated with unopposed estrogen stimulation. This unopposed stimulation is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia, which can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). Patients with AUB with a normal initial laboratory workup and a negative pregnancy test should be evaluated based on their bleeding pattern and risk factors for endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 72-year-old nulliparous woman with diabetes and obesity presents with vaginal spotting for 2 days. She had menopause at age 55 and takes tamoxifen for breast cancer. Pelvic examination shows minimal blood with a normal-sized uterus. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Refer to gynecology for urgent endometrial sampling
Order CT pelvis and discharge if normal
Prescribe estrogen cream and schedule routine gynecology follow-up
Start progestin therapy and schedule routine gynecology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Routine primary care follow-up is inappropriate for any patient with postmenopausal bleeding. This symptom requires prompt evaluation to rule out endometrial cancer, which typically presents with painless abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Urgent gynecologic referral for endometrial sampling is indicated for patients with postmenopausal bleeding who have risk factors for endometrial cancer. This patient has multiple risk factors including nulliparity, diabetes, obesity, and tamoxifen use. All patients with abnormal vaginal bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer should undergo endometrial sampling as the first-line diagnostic modality.

C) INCORRECT:

CT pelvis is not part of the initial evaluation for postmenopausal bleeding. Additional imaging studies may be ordered by specialists for staging purposes after a diagnosis is confirmed, but tissue sampling through gynecologic referral is the appropriate next step for this high-risk patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Estrogen therapy is contraindicated in the setting of unexplained postmenopausal bleeding and could potentially worsen underlying endometrial pathology. Unopposed estrogen exposure is a major risk factor for endometrial cancer, and this patient is already on tamoxifen, which acts as an estrogen agonist in endometrial tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Empirical progestin therapy without tissue diagnosis is inappropriate for postmenopausal bleeding evaluation. Progestin therapy is used for managing confirmed endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, but endometrial sampling should be performed in all patients with abnormal vaginal bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer to evaluate for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia or endometrial cancer before initiating any hormonal treatment.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old G3P3 woman presents to the clinic with two weeks of painless vaginal bleeding. She completed menopause at age 52 and does not use hormone replacement therapy. Her hypertension is controlled with oral medication. She has no significant family history of gynecologic malignancy. Her body mass index is 31 kg/m². Pelvic examination reveals a small amount of bright red blood in the vaginal vault with no visible cervical or vulvar lesions. The uterus is of normal size on bimanual exam, and there is no adnexal tenderness.
What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient’s postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In postmenopausal women with vaginal bleeding, endometrial biopsy is crucial for evaluating potential endometrial pathology, such as hyperplasia or carcinoma. This patient has risk factors, including obesity, which increase the likelihood of endometrial abnormalities. The biopsy provides direct histologic evaluation of the endometrial tissue, allowing for the identification of malignant or pre-malignant changes. It is a minimally invasive procedure typically performed in an outpatient setting, making it an essential step in the diagnostic process for postmenopausal bleeding.

Key learning point: In cases of postmenopausal bleeding, an endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step to assess for endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

The Papanicolaou test is primarily for cervical cancer screening and does not reliably detect endometrial pathology. In postmenopausal bleeding, especially without abnormal cervical findings, the focus is on endometrial causes. The Pap smear's low sensitivity for endometrial disease makes it inadequate for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Saline infusion sonohysterography enhances visualization of the endometrial cavity, useful for detecting focal lesions like polyps. However, it does not provide histopathologic evaluation needed for diffuse endometrial conditions such as hyperplasia or carcinoma, which are primary concerns in postmenopausal bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic hysteroscopy allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity and targeted biopsy of lesions. However, it is more invasive and typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations, like endometrial biopsy or ultrasound, are inconclusive or suggest focal pathology. It is not the first step in evaluating postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 3 months. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years and menses occurred at regular 30-day intervals until they became irregular 1 year ago. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows nodules and pustules along the jaw line and dark hair growth around the umbilicus. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized, retroverted uterus. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometriomas (chocolate cysts) are caused by endometriosis, which occurs when endometrial tissue develops outside the uterus. PCOS is not considered a risk factor for endometrioma or endometriosis.
Image Description:

A large bisected ovarian cyst

The cyst is filled with coagulated blood from endometriosis, giving it a chocolate-like appearance.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervical carcinoma is associated with infection with high-risk strains of HPV (e.g., HPV 16, 18, 31, 33). Other risk factors for cervical carcinoma include early onset of sexual activity, multiple sexual partners, multiple pregnancies, immunosuppression, previous sexually transmitted diseases, and smoking. PCOS is not considered a risk factor for cervical carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Choriocarcinoma requires implantation of a fertilized egg, and can develop during or after a pregnancy. Most cases of choriocarcinoma are preceded by molar pregnancy. Patients with PCOS are usually anovulatory and have decreased fertility, which decreases the risk of choriocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Mature cystic teratomas are the most common type of ovarian germ cell tumors. They are usually well differentiated, benign, and can contain any type of tissue (e.g., hair, teeth, and sebaceous glands). Mature cystic teratomas are not associated with PCOS.
Image Description:

Resection specimen of a mature teratoma of the ovary

This sebaceous and solid ovarian tumor contains skin, fat, hair, and cartilage.

Mature teratomas can derive from all three embryological germ layers.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial adenocarcinoma due to unopposed estrogen exposure. In PCOS, peripheral insulin resistance causes hyperinsulinemia, which increases androgen production from theca cells and estrogen conversion from granulosa cells. Increased androgen levels inhibit the production of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) in the liver, which further increases circulating estrogen levels.

PCOS is a common cause of infertility, due to disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, leading to increased LH secretion, impaired follicle maturation, and anovulation.
questions.hint: This patient is obese and has acne, oligomenorrhea, and hirsutism, which are findings consistent with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
